solution:
\begin{soln}
  As $\lim_{n \to \infty} \frac{a_{n+1}}{a_n}=\frac{1}{2}$, so
  for all $\eps > 0$ there exists $N\in \NN$
  such that for all $n\ge N$,
  \[
  \left\lvert \frac{a_{n+1}}{a_n}-\frac{1}{2}
  \right\rvert <\varepsilon
  .\]

  This gives us the following inequality,
  \[
    \frac{1}{2}-\varepsilon < \frac{a_{N+i}}{a_{N+(i-1)}}
    <\frac{1}{2}+ \varepsilon
  \]
  for all $1\le i\le k$ where $k$ is some fixed natural number
  $\ge 1$. Now note that if we take $\varepsilon<\frac{1}{2}$,
  then everything on both the sides of the inequality is
  positive. So we can multiply them which gives,
  \[
  \left( \frac{1}{2}-\varepsilon\right)^{k} <\frac{a_{N+k}}{a_N}
  <\left( \frac{1}{2}+\varepsilon \right)^{k}
  .\]

  Limiting $k\to \infty$, by Sandwich theorem,
  we get that $\lim_{n \to \infty} a_{n} = 0$.

  Therefore,
  \[
  \lim_{n \to \infty} \frac{e^{a_{n}^2}+a_{n}}{4}
  =\frac{1}{4}
  .\qedhere
\]
\end{soln}
